sentences: Onzy Durrett Matthews, Jr. (January 15, 1930 â€“ November 13, 1997) was an American jazz pianist, singer, arranger and composer as well as a television and movie actor.
section: N/A

sentences: He is best known for the big band arrangements done for the Lou Rawls albums Black and Blue and Tobacco Road, as well as arrangements for several of Ray Charles' 1960s releases.
section: N/A

sentences: He had his own big band for many years and recorded numerous tracks for Capitol Records, including two albums released under his own name.
section: N/A

sentences: He later had a close relationship with the Duke Ellington orchestra, working as a pianist, arranger and conductor through the late 1960s and 1970s.
section: N/A
== Biography ==

sentences: Biography ==
section: == Biography ==
== Biography == | === Early days and move to Los Angeles ===

sentences: Early days and move to Los Angeles ===
section: == Biography == | === Early days and move to Los Angeles ===

sentences: Onzy Durrett Matthews, Jr. was born on January 15, 1930 to Onzy Matthews and Leola Jones in Fort Worth, Texas.
section: == Biography == | === Early days and move to Los Angeles ===

sentences: He grew up in Dallas until his early teens when his mother moved to Los Angeles seeking better paying work.
section: == Biography == | === Early days and move to Los Angeles ===

sentences: His early exposure to music was through singing in a church gospel choir.
section: == Biography == | === Early days and move to Los Angeles ===

sentences: Matthews knew early on he wanted to be a musician: "music was his calling."
section: == Biography == | === Early days and move to Los Angeles ===

sentences: He graduated from high school early, at the age of 16, and primarily wanted to be a singer.
section: == Biography == | === Early days and move to Los Angeles ===

sentences: "I taught myself to accompany myself on piano and then I found out you had to have arrangements."
section: == Biography == | === Early days and move to Los Angeles ===

sentences: In the early 1950s he enrolled in the Westlake College of Music in Hollywood and studied voice, ear training and harmony; much like Berklee School of Music they were proponents of the Schillinger System.
section: == Biography == | === Early days and move to Los Angeles ===

sentences: He auditioned for band leader Les Brown as an arranger;   Brown helped Matthews focus on what to keep in an arrangement that works, and what to discard.
section: == Biography == | === Early days and move to Los Angeles ===
== Biography == | === First breaks with Dexter Gordon and Curtis Amy ===

sentences: First breaks with Dexter Gordon and Curtis Amy =
section: == Biography == | === First breaks with Dexter Gordon and Curtis Amy ===
== Biography == | === First breaks with Dexter Gordon and Curtis Amy ===

sentences: In 1959, Matthews contacted Dexter Gordon who was active in the Los Angeles jazz scene at the time.
section: == Biography == | === First breaks with Dexter Gordon and Curtis Amy ===

sentences: Matthews' first big band was started with the help of Gordon and fellow saxophonist Curtis Amy.
section: == Biography == | === First breaks with Dexter Gordon and Curtis Amy ===

sentences: The group started with a book of 21 charts from Matthews, and rehearsed on Wednesday nights for 5 months until they finally booked gigs in the area.
section: == Biography == | === First breaks with Dexter Gordon and Curtis Amy ===

sentences: The group was a conglomerate of all-star Los Angeles jazz/studio artists who immediately took a liking to playing Matthews' inventive, blues-based orchestrations; the first players coming through his band included Gordon, Amy, Sonny Criss, Jack Sheldon, Carmell Jones, and Red Mitchell.
section: == Biography == | === First breaks with Dexter Gordon and Curtis Amy ===

sentences: Curtis Amy included two of Matthews' original tunes on his Pacific Jazz albums Meetin' Here and Way Down in 1961 and 1962 respectively.
section: == Biography == | === First breaks with Dexter Gordon and Curtis Amy ===

sentences: Dexter Gordon recorded Matthews' original tune "Very Saxily Yours" for his Gettin' Around album on Blue Note, but the track was not released until 25 years later on the CD re-issue.
section: == Biography == | === First breaks with Dexter Gordon and Curtis Amy ===

sentences: Matthews became known around Los Angeles as an adept arranger and musical director; his first professional arranging assignments came at this time with Lionel Hampton, Della Reese, Ruth Price, and Gene McDaniels.
section: == Biography == | === First breaks with Dexter Gordon and Curtis Amy ===

sentences: The first tune of Matthews to be commercially recorded was in 1956, when clarinetist Maurice Meunier, who had played with Lionel Hampton, recorded in France.
section: == Biography == | === First breaks with Dexter Gordon and Curtis Amy ===

sentences: Meunier had got a copy of Matthews' "Blues for the Reverend" through his association with the Hampton band the year before.
section: == Biography == | === First breaks with Dexter Gordon and Curtis Amy ===
== Biography == | === Racial discrimination and problems with recording companies ===

sentences: Racial discrimination and problems with recording companies ===
section: == Biography == | === Racial discrimination and problems with recording companies ===

sentences: Much like other black jazz artists of that time, it was particularly difficult for Matthews to break prejudice and color barriers.
section: == Biography == | === Racial discrimination and problems with recording companies ===

sentences: He said at the time: "They said the band was too mixed, a couple of whites or a couple of Negroes would be O.K. but not 50/50."
section: == Biography == | === Racial discrimination and problems with recording companies ===

sentences: He was confronted by an agent who hired an all-white group for a Las Vegas show rather than Matthews' mixed band.
section: == Biography == | === Racial discrimination and problems with recording companies ===

sentences: His frustration extended to A&R representatives for Decca, Columbia, and Capitol, who liked the sound of the band and his music but expressed concern after seeing the racially mixed band in person.
section: == Biography == | === Racial discrimination and problems with recording companies ===
== Biography == | === Onzy Matthews Big Band ===

sentences: Onzy Matthews Big Band ===
section: == Biography == | === Onzy Matthews Big Band ===

sentences: Matthews' group in the early 1960s was finding work as a big band in Los Angeles; most of his players were shared, alternating with Gerald Wilson's big band (another integrated big band) every other weekend at the Metro Theatre in Los Angeles.
section: == Biography == | === Onzy Matthews Big Band ===

sentences: The group also had a long running gig on Monday nights at the Virginia Club in Los Angeles.
section: == Biography == | === Onzy Matthews Big Band ===

sentences: Players for Matthews' big bands and recordings in Los Angeles included Bud Brisbois, Curtis Amy, Bobby Bryant, Dick Hyde, Teddy Edwards, Earl Palmer, Jay Migliori, Conte Candoli, Richard 'Groove' Holmes, Horace Tapscott, Gabe Baltazar, Joe Maini, Ollie Mitchell, Herb Ellis, Carmell Jones, Sonny Criss, and Jack Nimitz.
section: == Biography == | === Onzy Matthews Big Band ===

sentences: These included both black and white studio musicians, which  continued to present a problem until Matthews worked with the much younger producer Nick Venet after he signed to Capitol.
section: == Biography == | === Onzy Matthews Big Band ===

sentences: Singers that Matthews featured and wrote for, on their regular live gigs, included Ruth Price, Jimmy Witherspoon, Big Miller, and June Eckstine.
section: == Biography == | === Onzy Matthews Big Band ===
== Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===

sentences: Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records =
section: == Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===
== Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===

sentences: Lou Rawls was signed to Capitol Records in early 1961 and had a breakthrough set of hits with Les McCann and the album Stormy Monday.
section: == Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===

sentences: Nick Venet was in charge of Rawls, and introduced him to Matthews.
section: == Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===

sentences: In August 1962, they recorded 13 new charts arranged by Matthews that featured Rawls' resonating baritone voice.
section: == Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===

sentences: Eleven of those charts would comprise Rawls' LP Black and Blue, which charted for three weeks in Billboard magazine from April 1963, reaching no.130.
section: == Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===

sentences: Both men were back in the studio at Capitol in July and August 1963 to record more tracks, which made up Rawls' album Tobacco Road.
section: == Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===

sentences: Both albums were re-issued in 1969 on a Capitol release, Close-Up, which charted for three weeks in Billboard starting in August 1969, peaking at no.191.
section: == Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===

sentences: The band for the two Rawls LPs is essentially the personnel of the Onzy Matthews big band from that time.
section: == Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===

sentences: Matthews' arranging style was a perfect fit for Rawls, but the pair did not re-unite for any other releases for Capitol.
section: == Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===

sentences: Two other sets of singles sessions with Rawls from 1963 have never been issued.
section: == Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===

sentences: Matthews' band continued to back Lou Rawls on live concerts and events during the late 1960s.
section: == Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===

sentences: A second high-profile Matthews arranging assignment during this time was for Jac Holzman, who used him to arrange the traditional jazz ensemble tracks for Judy Henske's 1963 debut album for Elektra Records.
section: == Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===

sentences: Matthews was finally signed to Capitol by Venet, and his first LP Non-Stop Jazz Samba was recorded in February 1963.
section: == Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===

sentences: However, the album was not released.
section: == Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===

sentences: It has three different instrumentations of ensembles, with his big band as the core.
section: == Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===

sentences: Matthews showed his adeptness at a wide range of writing; the tracks are somewhat like Quincy Jones' 1962 album Big Band Bossa Nova released by Mercury Records.
section: == Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===

sentences: There are other unissued jazz sessions that Matthews arranged from this time with Dupree Bolton for Pacific Jazz, and tracks with Richard 'Groove' Holmes recorded at Capitol.
section: == Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===

sentences: Later, Holmes had Matthews arrange all the tracks for his own release Book of Blues: Volume I in 1964 for Warner Bros. Records, backed by Matthews' big band.
section: == Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===

sentences: Matthews wrote more charts and supplied the same band on Holmes' November 1966 release A Bowl of Soul, also with Warner Bros. Records.
section: == Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===

sentences: In January 1964, Matthews recorded his first commercially released LP under his own name for Capitol: Blues with a Touch of Elegance.
section: == Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===

sentences: Though not a financial success, the LP is widely known by musicians and music critics as a masterpiece of jazz composing and arranging.
section: == Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===

sentences: The initial Billboard review was extremely positive putting it in the "Jazz: Special Merit" category.
section: == Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===

sentences: Lefty Louie/Blues Non-Stop, a quartet backed by voices, was also recorded during these sessions and was released as a single on the Capitol label.
section: == Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===

sentences: July 1964 saw the next Matthews' Capitol album recorded, Sounds of the '60s, but it was not issued until spring 1966.
section: == Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===

sentences: The album is not as cohesive a project as the first release and did not achieve the same fame as Blues With a Touch of Elegance.
section: == Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===

sentences: In October 1966, Matthews was assigned to write for Esther Phillips.
section: == Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===

sentences: His charts were recorded live in 1970, and appeared on the Atlantic release Confessin' the Blues, one of Phillips' best recordings.
section: == Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===

sentences: The Phillips release has frequently been miscredited as having been recorded in 1976, due to its repackaging as a compilation; again Matthews' big band backs the primary artist.
section: == Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===

sentences: His other arranging assignments for recordings included work for Herb Alpert and Curtis Amy's 1965 LP
section: == Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===

sentences: The Sounds of Broadway/The Sounds of Hollywood for Palomar Records.
section: == Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===

sentences: He did some writing for Lloyd Price's big band and also the Jazz with Steve KTLA
section: == Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===

sentences: T.V. show from Los Angeles in 1963.
section: == Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===

sentences: From then o,n there were no more releases by Matthews as leader for Capitol or any other recording label; much was recorded with Capitol and finally released for the first time on the Mosaic Select 29 CD set in 2007.
section: == Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===

sentences: Matthews was known as a singer, but the only documentation of this is on the 2007 Mosaic set.
section: == Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===

sentences: Producer Michael Cuscuna found three tracks Matthews recorded during this era in July and October 1964, where he overdubbed his singing while fronting his big band.
section: == Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===

sentences: These had never been issued before the Mosaic set was issued.
section: == Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===

sentences: The Onzy Matthews big band was recorded far more on other artists' releases, primarily backing singers, than under his own name.
section: == Biography == | === Breakthrough with Lou Rawls and Capitol Records ===
== Biography == | === Ray Charles and other writing ===

sentences: Ray Charles and other writing
section: == Biography == | === Ray Charles and other writing ===
== Biography == | === Ray Charles and other writing ===

sentences: During the mid-1960s, Matthews was able to parlay his earlier arranging success into being offered numerous arranging assignments with singer Ray Charles.
section: == Biography == | === Ray Charles and other writing ===

sentences: All these tracks were recorded for ABC-Paramount.
section: == Biography == | === Ray Charles and other writing ===

sentences: In March and June 1965, two arrangements by Matthews were recorded for Charles' album Country & Western meets Rhythm & Blues.
section: == Biography == | === Ray Charles and other writing ===

sentences: He had one arrangement on the 1966 album Ray's Moods, and three more on Charles' Cryin' Time.
section: == Biography == | === Ray Charles and other writing ===

sentences: Both these 1966 albums charted with Billboard.
section: == Biography == | === Ray Charles and other writing ===

sentences: One last chart completed for Ray Charles was done for the single "That's All I Am To You".
section: == Biography == | === Ray Charles and other writing ===

sentences: Matthews arrangement of Driftin' Blues on Cryin' Time is noted as a standout that features a guitar solo by Ray Crawford.
section: == Biography == | === Ray Charles and other writing ===

sentences: More writing assignments during this time include arranging for television shows such as the June 29, 1965 CBS special, It's What's Happening, Baby!
section: == Biography == | === Ray Charles and other writing ===

sentences: featuring numerous contemporary pop acts.
section: == Biography == | === Ray Charles and other writing ===
== Biography == | === Acting career ===

sentences: Acting career ===
section: == Biography == | === Acting career ===

sentences: Matthews first worked in Los Angeles night clubs as a singer in the 1950s, and became known as a personality.
section: == Biography == | === Acting career ===

sentences: He had his first television appearance on the KLAC-TV show Hollywood
section: == Biography == | === Acting career ===

sentences: On Television hosted by Al Jarvis, where he sang in duet with co-host Betty White (her first T.V. work).
section: == Biography == | === Acting career ===

sentences: He also broke into acting around Hollywood; Matthews was tall, handsome, and very well spoken.
section: == Biography == | === Acting career ===

sentences: He appeared in the July 1965 NBC Kraft Suspense Theatre episode Connery's Hand and also the February 14, 1966 episode In Search of April from Run for Your Life starring Ben Gazzara which also ran on NBC.
section: == Biography == | === Acting career ===
== Biography == | === Duke Ellington, Paris, last move to Dallas ===

sentences: Duke Ellington, Paris, last move to Dallas ===
section: == Biography == | === Duke Ellington, Paris, last move to Dallas ===

sentences: Matthews and his band went on a three-week tour in 1966 for Capitol Records to promote his second album for the label (Sounds of the '60s!).
section: == Biography == | === Duke Ellington, Paris, last move to Dallas ===

sentences: During a stop in New York City, he met Mercer Ellington and as a result became a piano substitute for Duke Ellington.
section: == Biography == | === Duke Ellington, Paris, last move to Dallas ===

sentences: He undertook several collaborations with the Duke Ellington Orchestra through the 1970s as an arranger.
section: == Biography == | === Duke Ellington, Paris, last move to Dallas ===

sentences: He co-wrote an unrecorded composition with Ellington, Just a Gentle Word from You Will Do.
section: == Biography == | === Duke Ellington, Paris, last move to Dallas ===

sentences: Several years after Duke Ellington died, Matthews had a disagreement in 1979 with Mercer Ellington, and later had to settle a pay dispute with Ellington's son arising from Matthews' uncredited arrangements on the 1996 Musicmasters Records CD release Only God Can Make A Tree.
section: == Biography == | === Duke Ellington, Paris, last move to Dallas ===

sentences: During the 1970s, Matthews arranged music for albums by Earl Hines and Roy Ayers; he also worked on television music for Paul Anka.
section: == Biography == | === Duke Ellington, Paris, last move to Dallas ===

sentences: At that time, he moved around between New York, Dallas and Seattle, and at one point worked for Sheraton Resorts in the Virgin Islands, Aruba, and CuraÃ§ao as solo pianist and singer.
section: == Biography == | === Duke Ellington, Paris, last move to Dallas ===

sentences: Disenchanted by much of the musical scene, in 1979 Matthews moved to Paris and started another jazz orchestra.
section: == Biography == | === Duke Ellington, Paris, last move to Dallas ===

sentences: Working from there as a composer, arranger, and actor, he appeared in the movie Dingo (1991) playing the trumpeter Caesar alongside Miles Davis.
section: == Biography == | === Duke Ellington, Paris, last move to Dallas ===

sentences: Matthews returned to New York in 1993 after a financially devastating operation for prostate cancer.
section: == Biography == | === Duke Ellington, Paris, last move to Dallas ===

sentences: Mercer Ellington offered Matthews work on his father's Sacred Concert music as an arranger.
section: == Biography == | === Duke Ellington, Paris, last move to Dallas ===

sentences: Matthews also contributed string arrangements for Vanessa Rubin's I'm Glad There Is You album done for RCA Novus during this time.
section: == Biography == | === Duke Ellington, Paris, last move to Dallas ===

sentences: Prompted by his mother's death, in 1994 he moved back to Dallas to be with his father; his father died on May 26, 1995.
section: == Biography == | === Duke Ellington, Paris, last move to Dallas ===

sentences: Onzy Matthews had a last set of tours and concerts in Europe and Dallas, conducting his own music and that of Duke Ellington in 1996â€“1997; an interview by the Dallas Observer three months before his death outlined his musical career.
section: == Biography == | === Duke Ellington, Paris, last move to Dallas ===

sentences: Matthews died at the age of 67 on November 13, 1997 in his Dallas apartment, of heart failure brought on by arteriosclerosis.
section: == Biography == | === Duke Ellington, Paris, last move to Dallas ===
== Musical legacy ==

sentences: Musical legacy ==
section: == Musical legacy ==

sentences: In 2007 Michael Cuscuna produced a set of recordings for Mosaic documenting the music from Onzy Matthews' Capitol recordings.
section: == Musical legacy ==

sentences: This set comprises the two albums he released with his big band plus all the other unissued material recorded at Capitol by Matthews with his band.
section: == Musical legacy ==

sentences: The first LP, the bossa nova project from 1963, was not put on the market at the time, despite its writing and playing being equal to anything happening during that time in jazz and pop music.
section: == Musical legacy ==

sentences: Matthews' big bands recorded much more on other artists' LPs than under his own name.
section: == Musical legacy ==

sentences: He was in demand as an arranger for numerous singers, and the band had a level of success that translated into being a very good live "club date" band and "studio" orchestra.
section: == Musical legacy ==

sentences: His music and his band never got a real opportunity to stand on its own.
section: == Musical legacy ==

sentences: He was an important part of several different musical and cultural movements on the West Coast during the 1950s and 1960s.
section: == Musical legacy ==

sentences: Matthews was part of the Central Avenue music scene in the 1950s and grew musically from interaction with important jazz musicians such as Lionel Hampton, Dexter Gordon, and Curtis Amy.
section: == Musical legacy ==

sentences: He also trained at the Westlake College of Music with great composers and arrangers such as Bill Holman, Gary Peacock, Bob Cooper, and Bob Graettinger.
section: == Musical legacy ==

sentences: Matthews is enigmatic and a hard person to pinpoint; in many ways he did not get nearly the credit he deserved in comparison with big band leaders or musical directors such as Oliver Nelson, Gerald Wilson, or Harold Wheeler.
section: == Musical legacy ==
